entry.title: Re: Configure a tile on SAP Build Work Zone to manage Decision artifacts
entry.content:
• Make sure to refresh the HTML5 apps in WZ
  • Make sure you have a service key with 8 html5-apps-repo values
  • Make sure your destination has those values
  • Make sure your client ID and secret are correct in the destination
  • Make sure you deployed a decision 
  • Make sure you have permission for the Studio Home 
  • ID of decision
  • ID of environment
  • Other parameters under navagation

Anybody else: what else could it be?

entry.title: Find the Bug üêû Formatting dates and times in Build Apps
entry.content:
Someone sent me a problem they were having in a private message, that made me chuckle.

To be honest, after 2 years of war and 2 weeks of intense war, and having to live out of a suitcase for a week in Athens because my plane was diverted and could not enter my country -- this was a fun, amusing diversion (it actually made me laugh).

Here's the message I received:

FORMAT_DATETIME_WITH_TIMEZONE(DATETIME("2025-04-03T02:00:00.000Z"), "MMM d, yyyy", "America/Chicago")

"I am using formula to format the date. Actually the output should be Apr 2, 2025, 9 pm. But I am getting Apr 3, 2025, 9 pm. How to solve this? I tried multiple ways. It's only changing time but not date. I used other timezone format as well. Please help. This is an issue in production."

After running the formula in my Build Apps and getting the same result, I assumed it was a bug in the tool (@Mari and @Pekka_Aaltonen, please forgive me). For the programmer, the obvious thing to think was that you asked for the date in the format April 2 (because it had to give the day before because the time zone they gave was minus 6 hours from UTC) and instead it was giving April 3. Why? Probably because the formula was too stupid to return the previous day's date.

It was supposed to show this:

But kept showing this:

But, alas, there was a perfectly logical explanation, but it was hidden because of the actual date and time used in the example. Another case of all-too-human error.

Can you find the bug?

P.S.: If you like this puzzle, wait for Devtoberfest in October. We'll have plenty more.

It was supposed to show this:

entry.title: Send OData Batch Requests in SAP Build Apps (JSON)
entry.content:
Many people have asked about sending OData batch requests via SAP Build Apps. It can be done, if your API accepts JSON-formatted payloads for batch requests.

Just use the HTTP Destination Request flow function.

Then set the following:

  • Destination: Create an integration with your destination that points to your API (no need to specify any entities).
  • Method: POST
  • Body Type: JSON
  • Request Body: Just define a page variable with the JSON schema you need, and set the values with a Set Page Variable flow function. More on this below.
  • Path: /$batch
  • Headers: Content-Type = application/json

Request Body

The request body would be something like this (here we are create new records):

{
    "requests": [
        {
            "id": "1",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON1",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 99,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        },
        {
            "id": "2",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON2",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 100,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        }
    ]
}

For my test, I already had the JSON above so I just put it in a JavaScript component, parsed it, and output it.

But you could create a page variable, and in your app populate the variable with your data. Then you could use this page variable for the request body.

Unfortunately, I could not find a way to use the more traditional multipart/mixed payload format from SAP Build Apps. If you can find a way, let us know.

{"api":"https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-eu-prod.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com"}

Otherwise, feel free to send private message and perhaps you can show me your setup.

entry.content:
Also, I would use the built-in DMS activities to do the work (unless you mostly copied that template and do not want to rework it).

For downloading, use:

  1. Select DMS (via destination)
  2. Download DMS Document (path to folder, file name, output path)

entry.title: Re: Multi Level Parallel Approval Workflow - SAP Build Pr...
entry.content:
I created a process that simulated your situation. And I found the branch did not proceed until all branches were finished. So if I have 2 branches with an approval in each, it waits for both to complete.

As for terminating the process when a rejection occurs, you could put the approvals in a subprocess (with variables for subject and user to approve) and then raise a "rejected" event which would terminate the process when either one rejected the approval.

If you wanted a rejection to terminate the branch but continue the process, I haven't figured out how to do that yet.

entry.title: Re: Find the Bug üêû Formatting dates and times in Build Apps
entry.content:
What is a formula variable? Can you show screenshots?

Also, it is nice to create a standing function for such conversions, but what was the cause of the bug, that is, why did the person's formula not work?

Sorry if I am dense üòê

entry.title: Re: Find the Bug üêû Formatting dates and times in Build Apps
entry.content:
Yes, but you changed the value of the date!!!??? And you are using a different function and not converting it to a different time zone!!!???

Besides, if I plug in your formula, I get this -- boith the date AND the time are now not what I wanted!!!

The problem was the the initial date was April 3 @ 03:00 (which we hardcoded for convenience) and we want to show that time in the Chicago timezone. But with the original formula it showed April 3 instead of April 2. So the mission is to find why the formula shows the wrong date and to fix the formula -- without changing the date/time in the formula.

Sorry if that wasn't clear.

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
entry.content:
The APIs for process automation are quite important to building integration scenarios with processes. But many people do not know how to get started, and even experienced users do not know how to work with environments or how to handle authentication or when an API key is needed.

So here is a guide to the APIs.

NOTE: I assume that you already know how to work with process automation, and you know the ins and outs of creating and triggering process projects using the SAP Build UI.

 

What can you do with APIs

If you just use forms to trigger a process, and then the process runs with actions and approval forms, you may not need to use the APIs. But most sophisticated processes will require you to make use of the APIs. So here is a list of some of things you can do with the APIs:

  • Trigger a process (sending in input values)
  • Get the status of a process instance
  • Get the context and execution log of a process instance
  • Change the status of a process instance (such as suspend or cancel)
  • Get a list of existing processes
  • Get a list of open user tasks
  • Approve or reject an approval form
  • Execute any form, and select which button of the form to simulate pressing
  • Call a decision (business rule) to get the appropriate output
  • Get a list of automation jobs that were run
  • ... and much more

 

Where to get information on APIs

The best place to go to get basic reference information about the APIs is, of course, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Search for Process Automation, and then under APIs you will see the package of APIs.

Click the SAP Build Process Automation package, and you will see 1 OData API and 6 REST API. The key APIs are the REST APIs. 

Here's a link to get to the SAP Build Process Automation package directly.

 

Authentication and Permissions

The most complex part of working with the APIs is the authentication, and understanding the types of authentication and what each enables you to do.

2 Main Authentication Methods

There are 2 main ways to perform OAuth2 authentication:

  • Client Credentials, where you are signing in as the service, which has essentially admin rights (but not complete access to all information)
  • User Token, where you are signing in as a user (you) with whatever rights you have been given, both in terms of process automation roles and permissions in a specific SAP Build environment (more on environments later)

Why is this important?

Because you often want to know who the user is who is calling the API. For example, when triggering a process, the user who makes the API call is the one listed in the Monitoring tab. If that's not important, you can use client credentials with a service key.

Or, if you are retrieving workflow instances from an environment, only a member from that environment with the correct permissions can access the workflow instances. Using client credentials with the client id/secret will not work.

Client Credentials

To connect, with Client Credentials, you send a Client ID and Client Secret, derived from the service key.

In the cockpit, where you created an instance of the SAP Build Process Automation service, you need to create a service key. 

You only need supply a name for the key.

Once you create the key, you can view the key's detail by clicking View.

This displays something like this:

You only need the following fields to log in:

  • api: The host of the APIs
  • clientid: Username
  • clientsecret: Password
  • url: Authentication URL to get the authorization token (the URL is this URL with /oauth/token appended)

So if you were setting up a destination, this is how it would work:

User Token

But many times, perhaps most times, you do not want to use a service user but you want to know who is making the call. This is important, for example, if the call is to approve the task, so only the user to whom the task is assigned should be updating the task. Or, as we mentioned above, only a real member of an environment can retrieve workflow instances from a shared environment.

With a destination, the only change you need to make is to change the Authentication field to OAuth2JWTBearer, and this will make sure to retrieve and send a token for the current user. All other destination fields are the same.

Environments

With the relatively new shared environments (i.e., all environments except Public), you sometimes need to indicate in the API call to which environment you are making the call to. For example, a process may be deployed to multiple environments, so when you call to trigger it, you need to specify in which environment to trigger it.

To do this, you add this query parameter:

?environmentId=MyEnvironment

Similarly, if you want to retrieve all the process instances from a particular environment, your API URL might look like this:

https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-us-prod.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=danielshared

 

Try Out on Accelerator Hub

Let's try to access our SAP Build Process Automation process instances from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Go to the GET workflow-instances API. On the left menu, click Workflow Instances, and then select the first API call.

Click Add New Environment on the right, and fill in the details using the values from your service key.

Call the environment My Trial BTP, select the authentication domain for your tenant (for my trial account it was http://authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/) and then when entering the consumer subdomain, only enter the subdomain for your subaccount. 

At the bottom indicate you want to save the environment for the future, and click Configure. It might take a minute for the configuration to save.

Then, on the right, select the environment, and click Run. You should get your workflow instances.

entry.title: Re: Issue with File Corruption When Downloading from DMS...
entry.content: Is the file OK when you view it with the DMS UI?

entry.title: Re: Multi Level Parallel Approval Workflow - SAP Build Pr...
entry.content:
For your scenario why don't you do something like this.

Create custom variables:

  • user1 -- holds the 1st approver for the current level
  • user2 -- holds the 2nd approver for the current level
  • currenlevel -- holds the current level that we are approving

Inputs into the process (or derived from your actions):

  • list of approvers
  • number of levels you need approval for

For demo purpose, I just created a form to supply this but you can get it from wherever.

So now we create a more modular process:

  • Use script task to set the current level = 1 and get the first approvers
  • Check if we need the next approval level
    • If we don't end (and set whatever flags you need)
    • If we need this level:
      • Branch to allow both approvers to approve (using the same form)
      • If either rejects, we end (and set whatever flags you need)
      • Otherwise, increment to the next level, and then go back to the condition.

Notes:

  • If you want to end immediately when one of the approvers reject, I will have to give that some more thought.
  • You likely will want some indication of whether the process ended with approval or with rejection. You will need a flag but this depends on the rest of your scenario.
  • You only need 1 form and one branch for the entire process, but depends on your scenario.
  • I have not worked much with custom forms, but I would not think that would affect the setup.

HTH,

üò∏
